Stuart Little.Action: Wakes George up energetically for their soccer game and encourages him despite his cold.
Scrambles back quickly after being blown by George's sneeze, then helps George put on his glasses.
Successfully hands out orange slices to the team, demonstrating helpfulness and responsibility.
Does not participate in the soccer game despite others playing, possibly indicating hesitance or being overlooked.
Does an excellent job handing out the orange slices, demonstrating responsibility and helpfulness.
Has not yet entered the soccer game despite limited time remaining, possibly indicating hesitation or lack of readiness.
Jokes about getting an assist after falling into the goal netting.
Expresses worry about not being allowed to play soccer anymore, showing vulnerability and openness.
Shares his feelings about restrictions and activities he can't do, demonstrating trust and sincerity with George.
Successfully remains on the ball during the soccer game until it scores a goal.
Playfully asks if he gets an assist after scoring, showing confidence and awareness of the game.
Ends up tangled in the goal netting and then falling several feet into the dust.
Expresses worry about not being allowed to play soccer anymore due to parental restrictions, showing some self-awareness but lack of control over circumstances.
Responds forgivingly to George after George accidentally kicks him into the goal, saying 'That's okay. Hey, you won the game. That's the main thing.'
Greets Will Wilson warmly and engages politely with both George and Will when they enter the room.
Shows imaginative play by pretending to fly the model airplane and making engine noises.
Becomes distracted and does not immediately respond when George asks for pliers, momentarily lost in fantasy.
Asks Snowbell for help to fix the plane despite Snowbell's sarcastic reluctance.
Turns to sleep dejectedly when George chooses to play with Will instead of him.
Acts panicked and yells about the plane going out of control, showing vulnerability and honesty.
Attempts to fix the plane by himself, opens the instruction book and tries to work on the controls.
Accidentally turns on the plane motor causing it to move uncontrollably.
Panics and yells that he can't turn off the plane when it starts moving.
Apologizes sincerely after destroying the kite and expresses willingness to fix it.
Acts fearfully and admits fault honestly after the accident.
Responses to family conflict by trying to see the bright side, acknowledges a bad day but remains optimistic.
Engages quietly in school, does not mock or disrupt, shows patience with others’ understanding (e.g., teacher and boy’s answer).
Calmly handles a difficult day with family tensions and stays optimistic, seeing the bright side despite challenges.
Physically maneuvers a massive book's page in class, demonstrating skill and resourcefulness.
Offers multiple classmates invitations to come over after school, showing friendliness and effort to include others.
Responds with understanding and without complaint when classmates decline invitations.
Does not push or argue when excluded from basketball game, accepts the situation quietly.
Calls on the teacher to answer a question, demonstrates eagerness and willingness to participate.
Explains longitude and latitude accurately and confidently in class, demonstrating knowledge and preparedness.
Tries to invite multiple classmates to come over, showing social confidence and initiative despite repeated polite rejections.
Receives no explicit invitation to join basketball game, hinting possible social exclusion or oversight but does not show overt frustration or failure.
Listens to Margalo's warnings and drives to protect both of them from the Falcon.
Encourages Margalo and shares excitement after a daring escape, smiling when called 'friend'.
Suggests caution by telling Margalo she is reducing herself to the Falcon's cruel level.
Guns the car and drives fast to escape the attacking falcon, showing quick reaction to danger.
Despite nervousness, takes a calculated risk by driving full speed over a metal grate acting like a drawbridge.
Thinks quickly to hide in a narrow plastic pipe, successfully losing his pursuer.
Expresses nervousness and hesitation about antagonizing the falcon.
Wraps Margalo's wing with gauze, expresses sympathy for her injury.
Shows polite and friendly behavior by introducing himself warmly and bowing.
Gently inquires about Margalo's living situation with concern.
Insists Margalo cannot go back out on the street while hurt, shows concern for her well-being.
Offers Margalo to use his cat's bed while he gets something else for her.
Reassures Margalo not to worry about Snowbell hurting her.
Insists on letting Margalo stay at home despite Mrs. Little's initial reluctance
Embarrassed when explaining his greeting ritual, showing sincerity
Finds Margalo and saves her life
Creates a comfortable, beautiful new 'home' space for Margalo and waits expectantly for her reaction.
Feeds Margalo with a little spoon and laughs, showing care and friendliness.
Waits expectantly for Margalo's reaction to the new home setup, showing confidence in his thoughtful preparation.
Feeds Margalo with a little spoon and laughs, demonstrating gentle care and social skill.
Does not intervene in the minor household teasing (Snowbell suggesting spilling something), which may show passivity in certain social contexts.
Stays home to take care of Margalo, showing concern for her well-being.
Expresses empathy and sympathy after learning about Margalo's difficult past.
Admits to feeling a bit restricted in his own life, showing vulnerability.
Insists on staying home to take care of Margalo instead of going to school.
Appears a little embarrassed about his mother's over-protectiveness.
Engages in empathetic conversation with Margalo, showing understanding of her situation.
Expresses a wish for adventure but acknowledges his limited activities (painting) while appreciating life as an adventure.
Tries to be confident and accept the 'adventure' by going outside despite previous reluctance.
Immediately trips over Snowbell's tinkle ball and falls down the front steps.
Trips over Snowbell's tinkle ball and falls down the steps.
Stands up and shakes his head to clear it, continuing on without fuss.
Gets hit by a rolled-up newspaper and clears his head again calmly.
Gallantly holds out a chair for Margalo and serves her food, attempts to entertain her by juggling peas, and smiles despite minor mishap.
Gallantly holds out a chair for Margalo, serves food thoughtfully, juggles peas to entertain her and smiles proudly despite minor mishap.
Offers popcorn and asks Margalo if she is cold on a rooftop night out.
Listens to Margalo share her dream and encourages her by relating his own struggles.
Expresses modesty when explaining how he fixed Margalo’s pin.
Finds and repairs Margalo's broken stickpin by carefully searching the sidewalk and fixing it skillfully in his dad's workshop.
Shares warm conversation and popcorn at the drive-in, displaying modesty when praised.
Allows Margalo to snuggle up to him as they watch the movie.
Laughs with Margalo when a pea lands on his head during a playful moment.
Volunteers to go down the drain to find the lost wedding ring, eager to help and view it as an adventure.
Volunteers to go down the drain to retrieve the ring himself, showing confidence and willingness to take on a difficult task.
Volunteers to descend into a dark, smelly, and cold drain to retrieve Mom's ring, showing readiness and bravery.
Waves bravely before being lowered into the drain, indicating confidence and willingness to take on challenge.
Describes the environment with vivid detail and keeps communicating with his family while descending, showing situational awareness and communication skills.
Fails to notice the fraying string and ultimately falls when the string breaks, leading to a dangerous situation.
Stuart ventures down the kitchen drain to look for the ring despite obvious danger.
Reassures family he is okay despite splashing and panic sounds.
Volunteers to go down the drain to look for the ring despite the obvious danger.
Informs family he is okay and attempts to grab the string but cannot reach it.
Holds on to the necklace and brings Margalo to safety, emerging to cheers from family.
Tells Margalo she is the best friend he ever had, showing sincere appreciation.
Calls out quickly with a solution ('I got it'), holds on to the necklace to help Margalo escape, and emerges to cheers from his family.
Wakes up and notices Margalo's stickpin on his pillow, shows concern about her absence.
Asks where Margalo is, indicating care and attention to others.
Looks unconvinced by parents' reassurances about Margalo, showing sincere concern.
Wakes up promptly to the alarm and notices Margalo's stickpin on his pillow, indicating awareness and attentiveness.
Jumps out of his chair asking about Margalo, showing alertness and concern.
Looks unconvinced by his parents’ reassurances about Margalo's absence, showing critical thinking and skepticism.
Does not try to directly investigate Margalo’s absence immediately, instead relying on others’ explanations.
Insists on searching for Margalo despite the danger, showing loyalty and care by calling her family and friend.
Refuses to let George come along, asks him to cover for him instead.
Persuades George to help by deception (cover story).
Decides to find Margalo despite risks and his small size, shows determination and resolve.
Formulates a plan to have George cover for him by lying to parents, showing strategic thinking.
Rejects George's offer to accompany him, insisting on doing it alone but asks George to help cover for him, demonstrating confidence in his abilities.
Does not convince George to join or find a companion yet, which could be seen as an omission of securing support on a risky mission.
Invites Snowbell to join him in looking for Margalo, expressing friendship and mutual support.
Shows concern for how others will perceive Snowbell (mentions George might say Snowbell ate him), indicating care about social bonds.
Leaves early for school play rehearsal without telling his mother because he is worried about Margalo.
Decides to go out looking for Margalo despite risks, showing initiative and responsibility.
Attempts to persuade Snowbell to join him by appealing to friendship and potential consequences, showing strategic social skill.
Leaves home early and keeps plans to himself to avoid worrying others, showing thoughtful prioritization.

Encourages perseverance and refuses to give up despite setbacks.
Politely tries to ask squirrels about the falcon.
Offers raisins to Snowbell even though cats don't eat them.
Suggests finding someone who really knows the streets to help.

Approaches Monte to seek help, showing social confidence and willingness to reach out to potentially useful contacts.
Shows concern for Snowbell's well-being by asking if he is all right when Snowbell is scared.
Encourages persistence and refuses to give up despite risks and warnings.

Speaks clearly and calmly during the phone call, giving reassuring information and maintaining control of the situation.
Remains composed when a woman discovers him using her phone, attempts to calm her down.

Confronts Falcon to get back the stolen ring for his mother.

Despite hesitation, he follows Falcon into the lair showing cautious engagement.
Confronts Falcon and demands the return of his mom's ring confidently, demonstrating assertiveness and clarity.

Initially hesitates, showing some doubt or fear before proceeding.
Fires a pin at Falcon in an attempt to defend himself and Margalo.
Uses quick thinking to create a parachute from his backpack to slow his fall, showing resourcefulness and determination to survive.
Calls out to the barge captain and first mate for help, trying to explain he is there by mistake.
Writes a heartfelt letter to his parents, sharing his predicament honestly and sincerely.
Scampers over a ton of rubbish and tries to call up to the boat captain and first mate for help.
Writes a letter explaining his situation and places it in a whiskey bottle to communicate with his family.
Despite danger and fear, stays calm enough to formulate a plan to reach out for help.
Writes a thoughtful letter to his parents, showing concern for their feelings even when in distress.
Expresses self-doubt and frustration ('Oh, I am so useless...'), demonstrating vulnerability and sincerity.
Keeps hope alive by recognizing the 'silver lining' and continues to persevere despite setbacks.

Confronts pigeons cautiously, grabs plastic fork as weapon

Questions the legality of dumping garbage and the plane in the river, showing awareness and critical thinking.
Reacts to the pigeons' stupidity with a resigned 'Oh, brother,' indicating he sees their lack of intelligence but does not let it deter him.
Initiates a rescue for Margalo, showing concern for a friend in danger.
Goes to rescue Margalo despite potential danger, showing initiative and bravery.
Communicates to George about his location when asked, showing some responsibility and awareness.
Is mourned deeply by friends who call him a friend, highlighting his positive impact.
No direct actions or statements in this excerpt; Stuart is reported dead by other characters.
Persists in trying to start the plane despite others laughing at him.
Asks for help politely ('Anyone care to give me a push?') despite ridicule.
Does not respond with anger or embarrassment to Dowzer and Snoop's laughter.
Risks his safety to come immediately to Margalo's rescue when Falcon threatens her.
Ignores Margalo's plea to leave for her safety, insisting on confronting Falcon.
Arrives timely in his plane to confront Falcon and save Margalo, demonstrating quick thinking and bravery.
Attempts to fight Falcon by opening bomb bay doors and dropping rusty bolts, showing resourcefulness.
Is initially stunned by Falcon’s aggressive reaction and the unexpected somersault maneuver of the plane, indicating momentary surprise.
Turns at the last instant to avoid colliding with Snowbell and the paint can, showing awareness and consideration for others' safety.
Pilots a plane skillfully to avoid a collision by flying into and out of a shed window, outmaneuvering the pursuing Falcon.
Flies low and heads straight for a shed without apparent hesitation or error, demonstrating confident and quick thinking.
Draws courage to pull up his plane to avoid crashing when frightened.
Refuses to abandon Margalo despite danger, wants to protect her.
After being attacked and nearly crashing, Stuart pulls himself together quickly, regains control of the plane, and avoids crashing by responding to the sight of his family.
Paralyzed with fear and covers his eyes instead of immediately reacting to the emergency when his plane is damaged and spiraling downward.
Refuses to abandon Margalo even when advised to do so, showing loyalty and determination rather than cautious retreat.
Formulates a plan upon seeing Falcon approaching after Margalo lands on his plane, showing presence of mind and strategic thinking.
Develops and shares a daring rescue plan with Margalo, determined to save the situation despite danger.
Leaps out of the plane just before impact, prioritizing safety but showing willingness to take risks.

Comes up with a risky plan to confront the falcon despite warnings it is suicidal.
Leaps out of the plane just before collision, showing quick thinking and timing.
Admits he is too heavy for Margalo to carry, recognizing a new limitation.

Realizes he is safe after falling and recovers quickly from the initial panic.
Excitedly plans and looks forward to holidays with Margalo, showing inclusiveness and anticipation of shared experiences.
Encourages Margalo by telling her she is as big as she feels and to spread her wings and soar.
Shares a sincere and affectionate hug with Margalo before her departure.
Recognizes and gently expresses sadness about Margalo’s impending departure.
